alert.note: Alert for York (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 09 at 5:29PM EST until further notice by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: .Waters levels are exceeding full pool conditions on the reservoir at the Ninety Nine Islands Dam on the Broad River. Levels will likely continue to rise through the evening hours, and flooding impacts are likely on the area immediately adjacent to the river channel. ...FLOOD WARNING IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 AM EST WEDNESDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. * WHERE...The Broad River channel upstream and downstream from the Ninety Islands Dam in Cherokee and York Counties in Upstate South Carolina. * WHEN...Until 1000 AM EST Wednesday. * IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 517 PM EST, Water levels on the Ninety Nine Islands Dam reservoir showed an elevation of 105.8 feet, above the full pool condition of 104 feet. Water levels continue to rise as runoff from heavy rainfall in upstream areas continues to work its way down the Broad River channel. At these water levels, flooding will likely develop on parts of Ninety Nine Ferry Road, Cherokee Ford Complex Access Road, and on downstream boat landings. Additional flooding is likely along and near Peoples Creek due to high water levels upstream of the dam. Conditions will need to be monitored overnight into Wednesday at the Highway 211 bridge as well as Kings Branch and Guymore Creek. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Cherokee Falls. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction: When it is safe to do so, please report flooding threatening roads or property to the National Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg by calling toll free, 1, 800, 2 6 7, 8 1 0 1, by posting on our Facebook page, or via Twitter using hashtag NWSGSP. Your message should describe the specific location where impacts occurred and the depth of flooding observed.
